title-group.article-title: Factors associated with length of stay and cost among pediatric hospitalizations with a primary ophthalmic diagnosis

article-meta.aff: 1Wilmer Eye Institute, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD
2Johns Hopkins Surgery Center for Outcomes Research, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Fasika Woreta, MD, MPH, Wilmer Eye Institute, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, 600 N. Wolfe St., Baltimore, MD, 21287, fworeta1@jhmi.edu

fn.p: Disclosures: None of the authors have any proprietary interests or conflicts of interest related to this submission.
Declaration of Interests: The authors report there are no competing interests to declare.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To investigate factors associated with prolonged length of stay and high cost among pediatric hospitalizations with a primary ophthalmic diagnosis.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This retrospective, cross-sectional study utilized data on pediatric admissions with a primary ophthalmic diagnosis from the multicenter 2016 Kids’ Inpatient Database. Multivariable logistic regression models adjusted for demographic, hospital, and admission characteristics were used to evaluate factors associated with prolonged stay and high cost, defined as exceeding the 75th percentile (>4 days and $12,642, respectively).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: An estimated 6,811 pediatric hospitalizations with a primary ophthalmic diagnosis in the United States in 2016 were included. On adjusted analysis, a prolonged length of stay was more likely with Medicaid (vs. private insurance, OR=1.19, 95% CI: [1.02, 1.40], p=0.03), non-trauma (vs. trauma, OR=2.77, 95% CI: [2.12, 3.63], p<0.001) and urban teaching hospitals (vs. rural, OR=3.48, 95% CI: [1.04, 11.69], p=0.04). A high cost of stay was more likely with higher income levels (Quartile 3 vs. 1, OR=1.30, 95% CI: [1.02, 1.67], p=0.04; Quartile 4 vs. 1, OR=1.49, 95% CI: [1.08, 2.05], p=0.02), private insurance (vs. Medicaid, OR=1.26, 95% CI: [1.04, 1.53], p=0.02), Western hospitals (vs. South, OR=2.74, 95% CI: [1.83, 4.12], p<0.001), and trauma (vs. non-trauma, OR=3.29, 95% CI: [2.57, 4.21], p<0.001). Children and young adults had higher odds of prolonged stay, while adolescents and young adults had higher odds of high cost compared to toddlers (p<0.05 for all).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Additional work addressing the factors associated with higher resource utilization may help promote the delivery of quality inpatient pediatric eye care.
